ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I developed better writing skills and more creative tecnhiques.

I learned about the lives and habits of ~7-8 geniuses throughout history (some of which were new to me), and I learned what it is they did that earned them the title of genius. In particular, we discussed the social relevance of genius and the role of sensationalism in creating the story and legacy of a genius. Additionally, the various habits of geniuses were discussed, which provides a guideline for us as students as to how we can be more effective and creative in our own work. The lessons on creativity were especially impactful and definitely opened my eyes on how to be a better student.

I now have a more refined definition of what genius is and I no longer have the misconceptions of associating success with genius or prodigy. Additionally, we went over "enablers of genius" in the class and by following the list we explored I will try to lead a more creative life.
Ability to think critically, structure an argument, read sources and pick apart their arguments, knowledge of the concept of genius through time and take aways for my own life
I learned to be a better writer and a lot of other content on creativity, art, neuroscience, etc.
Gained better understanding about the notion of genius. Learned how to write essays about individuals + concepts a bit better.
Reading and writing skills; the relationship between genius, success, prodigy, and creativity; the lives and works of geniuses like Leonardo, Mozart, Newton, etc.

I learned so much information about the concept of genius, including but not limited to its history and modern interpretations. I developed knowledge about what it takes for a person to produce genius work, and what factors may influence geniuses themselves.
understanding of specially-gifted kids and adjust the ways viewing them.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: I think the course had good reading and video material, but the essay prompts were very detailed, leaving little room for creativity.

The readings and videos prior to each class were very interesting, and they were efficient in relaying all the background info needed to understand each class's discussions. Sometimes the discussions could seem a bit repetitive as we went over this material again, but that did also serve to further cement the information in my mind. The weekly essays and options for re-writes provided very good feedback on writing skills, and I feel this course definitely helped to improve my writing. A particular strength of the course would be the engaging class discussions, led by  Craig and Jakub - they were always insightful and interesting; they  made attending class and doing the assignments extremely enjoyable and have definitely provided me with one of my best course experiences at Yale.

Strengths: Great professor/TA, really interesting subject matter
Cons: Maybe it would be nice if we covered more modern geniuses, but not a huge criticism

Strengths: improve your writing skills, resources (prof., TA, Writing center peer, etc.), Profs are always available to answer questions about planning essays or revising essays, engaging discussions during class, variety of course material

Weaknesses: the lecture (where the prof. goes over autobiographical stuff) can be a bit redundant with readings and is also a little dry. Also, I think we get off topic a lot of times in class, and so we end up not talking about the actual content sometimes.
There was little time between assignments and consequently the workload was very high. My biggest focus was on meeting the frequent deadlines.

Strengths: in class discussions are deep and interesting. Writing wise, you can improve your writing if you take advantage of the revisions.
Weaknesses: Sometime class discussion can be difficult because of lack of participation

Strengths: the papers were well-designed; the pace is fast but the workload is manageable for a summer class; the readings were very interesting; Professor Wright and Jakub were both very engaging.
Weaknesses: maybe it would be better to have fewer geniuses in the second of the half of the class but more information about each of them, I really liked the pace for geniuses in the first half (Leonardo, Newton, Mozart).
A strength is that it very thoroughly covers the concept of genius and will allow you to explore historical figures in depth from a new and intriguing perspective.

Teachers are all very insightful, devoted and patient. 
The forms are novel and effective.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes, I would recommend this course to another student interested in the topic, but there is a lot of work and the essay's are very specific, leaving little room for unique ideas.

Absolutely, both the teaching staff of this course and the material itself is very fascinating; the skills learned about creativity, habits of genius, and writing are all very useful and valuable for any college student.
I recommend this course to any student who wants to study geniuses such as Da Vinci, Newton, Einstein, Mozart ect., and who also wants to try to identify today's possible geniuses
Yes! The material was really interesting and left me with a lot of interesting things to ponder

Yes! If you are interested in genius and want a writing credit this is an excellent course. Be prepared though - it is a lot of work (especially if you take it during the summer). But you have plenty of resources to help you.
Yes! Very interesting content and great professor.
I would recommend this course to another student for a summer school session as the only course they take in a given session because the workload is heavy yet very engaging.

yes 
much to gain and help to formulate a brand new perspective
